author: Ellen Scott
title: Meet the artists taking down the pressure to be perfect
text:
(Picture: Phlegm._) 23-year-old Pip and 22-year-old Lib were fed up of being surrounded by adverts and pictures pressuring them to be perfect.
Instead of just moaning about it or feeling rubbish, they decided to do something: Phlegm._ .
You have to see the stunning images of the Sony World Photography Awards 2017 Phlegm._ is a collective dedicated to the idea of destroying perfection, and taking down feelings of unworthiness and imperfection as a result.
It’s the creation of Pip and Lib, who want to encourage people to be who they want, not who society tells us to be.
How, exactly, are they doing this? The same way we’re encouraged to feel terrible about ourselves: through words and pictures.
Pip takes the pictures, Lib does the words.
(Picture: Phlegm._) They met at uni, bonded over watching Prison Break, and discovered they were twin souls.
Pip is a ‘bit of a hippy at heart’, working as a photographer and selling shoes on Oxford Street to make money. Lib is ‘the female Jim Carrey’, is excellent at making hot chocolate, loves writing poetry, and works pulling pints and serving burgers.
‘We are just two girls who wanna change the world,’ Pip and Lib told metro.co.uk. ‘We think up weird ways to visualize our topics. It’s the kind of stuff that confuses our parents.’
(Picture: Phlegm._) They’re working on taking down perfection by tackling smaller issues one by one.
First they created a photo series about it being perfectly okay for men to cry. Because it should be.
Then they did a project about the objectification of women. Which shouldn’t be happening.
(Picture: Phlegm._) Gender roles are a massive part of the ideals the artists hope to dismantle, believing that the best way to equality is to forget expectations for both genders and start on an equal playing field.
‘The more something is exposed, the more normal it becomes,’ say Pip and Lib. We will knock down these silly social ideals, one by one
‘Each gender have these stupid expectations, just because you a born with a certain body part, you are expected to be a certain way.
‘It’s bloody ridiculous.
‘We’ve got to liberate both sexes.’
They’ve also taken to the streets to hand out leaflets explaining why the concept of perfection is a load of sh*t.
(Picture: Phlegm._) ‘It’s a concept which has been made up in dreamworld,’ Pip and Lib told us. ‘People get sucked into it and it damages their perception of reality, believing perfection, is the be all and end all.
‘If we keep focusing on pretty filters, likes and fitting in, we will miss the world going by.
‘If we could open people’s eyes, change their desire for perfection, then we would wear party hats for the rest of our lives.’
(Picture: Phlegm._) For now, they’re working on this dream through just their blog and leaflets, but they hope that one day they’ll be able to make snazzy t-shirts that people can wear as a ‘big fat f**k you to perfection.’

Their mission is simple; to make the world a little nicer, and spread the message: ‘Perfection is an arsehole. Don’t conform to it.’
We’re on board.
